ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FOREIGN SERVICE
(Training schemes for officers)


    1. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if there are formal training schemes for officers inducted into the foreign service; what forms these schemes take; and what amount of money was spent on these schemes during the years 1971 to 1973.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Ong Soo Chuan) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply.

    At the end of 1973, a Foreign Service Training Scheme was established for recruits to the Foreign Service. Prior to this date all training had been on an ad hoc basis supplemented with overseas training courses.

Column: 165

The ad hoc training consisted largely of a series of talks relevant to the Ministry and basic in- service training in the Ministry and in Overseas Missions. Trainees were also attached to various Government Ministries and Departments in Singapore for briefings on the policies and functions of the Ministries and Departments of Government and on matters relevant to the officer's work overseas. The first group of trainees to undergo the new form of training was appointed by the Public Service Commission to the Foreign Service in late 1973, and hence commenced their training in January 1974.

    The Foreign Service Training Scheme comprises four phases as follows:-

1st Phase - Basic Training

    This is a full-time, three-month period of training made up of lectures and seminars on Foreign Service subjects. For the academic portion of this training, lecturers from the University of Singapore and the Staff Training Institute of Singapore are also used. For the practical part of the training diplomats and Heads of Missions of the Singapore Foreign Service who have returned to Singapore are used.

    Courses on international relations, international law and international economics are some of the subjects taught with the assistance of the University of Singapore. There are also courses covering political and economic work, intelligence and social etiquette, protocol and consular work and personnel and financial administration. These are conducted with the assistance of the Ministries of Defence and Finance.

2nd Phase - Language Training

    This is a part-time, six-month period of training in a foreign language selected by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. During this phase of training, trainees are also attached to various Divisions of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other Government Ministries in Singapore.

    For language training the foreign language training courses conducted by the Adult Education Board, the

Column: 166

Language Centre of the University of Singapore as well as its Extra-curricular Studies Department are used. Also, where necessary, the Ministry makes available the services of private tutors for specific languages.

3rd Phase - Practical Training

    This is a full-time, three-month period of on-the-job training. The trainee is attached to the United Nations desk of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs which is the best available in Singapore "desk-type" training for young recruits to the Foreign Service.

4th Phase - Post-course Attachment

    This is a full-time, two-month period of attachment to a particular South Asian or South-east Asian country for practical training purposes. Alternatively, the recruit is sent as a member of official delegations to international conferences or meetings, or even as a member of the official delegation to the United Nations.

    Finally, under the Training Scheme, trainees are obliged to attend seminars and talks organised by the Institute of South-east Asian Studies and the University of Singapore, as well as the Ministry, on Foreign Service subjects.

    Apart from the above, scholarships and Colombo Plan awards for foreign service training and intensive foreign language training offered through the Public Service Commission are used to improve and upgrade the knowledge and experience of Foreign Service officers who have completed the Training Scheme and are working either in the Ministry Headquarters or in Overseas Missions.

    In 1971, a sum of $34,000 was spent on sending overseas officers on training courses awarded through the Public Service Commission. In 1972, expenditure on training increased to an amount of $48,000 when more officers became available for awards under the Colombo Plan for scholarships or training courses overseas on subjects relevant to the Foreign Service. In 1973, training was still largely ad hoc because the Training Scheme was not really implemented

Column: 167

until the first group of trainees became available in 1974. Expenditure in 1973, including expenditure on training course overseas (for example, the Foreign Service Training Course in Canberra) was $34,800.

PRIVATE CAR OWNERSHIP
(Government policy)


    2. Encik Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Communications if it is the policy of his Ministry to discourage private car ownership and to encourage the use of public transport; if he realises that the public transport services are inadequately and poorly serving the public; and if he will not introduce sudden and drastic measures to discourage private car ownership until the public transport services are improved.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is the deliberate policy of Government to restrain the growth of the private motor car population in Singapore. When new rates of taxes on motor cars were introduced in October 1972, it was then announced that the higher rates of taxes were made to discourage private car ownership and not for the purpose of raising revenue. However, the number of new motor car registrations for the period October 1972 to September 1973 was 20,459 which represented a 25 per cent increase over the new registrations for the corres-

Column: 168

ponding period from October 1971 to September 1972.

    We cannot sustain such a high growth rate except at tremendous economic and social cost. Therefore, taxes on cars had to be raised again in January this year. In the statement announcing these tax increases, the Finance Ministry again reiterated that this was not done to raise revenue but to discourage private car ownership. It was also stressed that if these increases did not have the desired effect, further revisions of the tax structure would be required until a balance is reached. I am happy to say that, this time, new registrations of private cars for January showed a 50 per cent reduction over new registrations in January last year, while new registrations in February were down by 28 per cent over new registrations in February 1973.

    It is regrettably true that the present public bus services need further improvement, especially service during peak hour travel. We have authorised a Supplementary Public Transport Service with 259 vehicles (of which 253 are school and other buses and six are goods vehicles) to provide an express, limited stop service, during peak hour periods. In addition, the reserved bus lanes which have been introduced and are being extended will give buses the priority they deserve on our limited road space.

    Whether or not there will be more drastic measures to check further increases in ownership of private cars depends on how many new cars will be registered this year, and in the years ahead. As incomes grow, so has the car owning group. The new taxes imposed since January, together with the steep increases in petrol prices caused by the doubling of the price of crude oil since January this year, appears to have had some effect in slowing down the growth of car owners for the time being. However, even with the present number of cars, it is already planned to have a park-and-ride scheme. Commuters will be able to park their cars in fringe car parks and take a special shuttle bus into or out of the Central Business

Column: 169

District (CBD) during peak periods. This would help to cut down traffic congestion during peak periods. Car pooling and staggered working hours will also greatly reduce congestion during peak periods.

    As at 28th February, there were 137,470 private cars registered for use on our roads. If the growth rate of 17 per cent per annum in new registrations in the last three years continues, it will be impossible to solve our traffic problems. We cannot increase our roads by a similar percentage each year. And in the CBD, the increase of road capacity is very limited, despite road widening and one-way traffic flows. The longer we delay action, the more painful and costlier the solutions will be. When car taxes went up in October 1972, all car owners were put on notice. All present and future car owners have to recognise the limits of our road capacity, especially in the CBD. By a combination of taxes on cars, parking fees, restricted entry into the CBD during peak hours and peripheral parking and reserved bus lanes, we must and can ensure maximum freedom of access to the CBD. This is essential to the vitality of the CBD and on our whole economy.

    An improvement in the public bus service is vital. It is the mainstay of our public transport system and would continue to be important even after we have a Mass Rapid Transit System. This may be in the late 1980's. The Singapore Bus Service Ltd is making the effort to match the Government's initiatives to get the bus services to meet ever higher needs. This year, there should be further improvement in the number of buses on the road and their standard of maintenance. The more difficult problem is to improve performance of bus drivers and conductors. Safer driving and more courteous service need a longer period of re-education. However, courtesy is a two-way process. Considerate conduct and co-operation of the commuters is a necessary contribution to a better bus service.

Therefore, are not all these measures only a means to encourage them to travel by buses operated by the SBS? That is the connection.

Car owners going into this CBD area would have to park their cars in the peripheral car parks and then jump on to the special shuttle bus

service, not necessarily the SBS. It has never been indicated that this shuttle bus service would be run by the SBS. The third alternative is the supplementary public bus service or, as somebody has called them, the school buses and lorry buses. They are available and they are a great boon to the travelling public.

And to discourage people from owning cars is already a cause for some people to raise the question: why should they upkeep a private monopoly? And therefore imposing such other measures would certainly cause adverse emotional reaction.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, evidently the Member for Kallang has not taken note of the answers to his questions. He has not, therefore, asked questions relevant to the answers. He goes off at a tangent. The reply given to his Oral Question on private car ownership was that all car owners had been given notice that taxes would go up and that it would be costly to maintain a private car. And if they do not take heed of such notice, then I suppose they might go to the Member for

Column: 172

Kallang and make a plea at his Meet-the-people sessions. I cannot afford to look at one aspect of the problem only but in the national interest, so that our City will progress economically. Just because he owns a car, it does not mean that he has the right to go anywhere he pleases. That is why we have introduced the reserved bus lanes so that priority is given to the public bus, not the private car.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: As I have said, Mr Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member is unable to follow the answers but keeps on talking of monopoly and nationalisation. He is obsessed by these two words. It is the duty of this Government to ensure that public transport is the best that is possible in the circumstances, and every effort will be made to ensure that this is so.

USE OF GOODS VEHICLES FOR PUBLIC TRANSPORT


    3. Encik Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Communications why goods vehicles have been used for public transportation to supplement the bus services operated by the Singapore Bus Service (Private) Limited; and if the use of such vehicles will be a permanent state of affairs.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, use of goods vehicles to transport passengers to and from work is nothing new. I am sure the hon. Member for Kallang would have seen, not so long ago, the numerous lorries carrying hundreds of civilian employees of the British military establishments to and from work everyday. Even today, if he were to go to Jurong, and I believe he does go to Jurong, he would see lorry after lorry carrying workers to and from work in the industrial estate.

    The hon. Member would be pleased to know that, to date, 103 goods

Column: 173

vehicles (all lorries) have been issued with licences for the carriage of passengers under the Supplementary Public Transport Service Scheme; of these, 97 are for Adult Worker Contract (AWC) permits and six Public Transport (PT) licences. Those who do not wish to travel on the public bus services provided by Singapore Bus Service Ltd (SBS), or school buses under the Supplementary Public Transport Service, scheme B, should not be prevented from travelling in goods vehicles if they so wish.

    Whether this supplementary service of goods vehicles being used for carriage of passengers would remain a permanent state of affairs depends on whether it would continue to be needed. Unless peak hour travel demand can be spread through staggered working hours, car-pooling, park-and-ride scheme and other measures, there would continue to be a need for the supporting role of the Supplementary Public Transport Service for peak hour travel, for the foreseeable future.

    Encik Abdul Aziz: Sir, can the scheme to permit goods vehicles to transport human cargo be considered a measure that will improve the public transport service? Is it appropriate to state that the bus services have deteriorated to a point commonly experienced in a protracted state of war and chaos?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member for Kallang used the words "human cargo". I would prefer to use the term "human passengers". As I have stated, it is the wish of a person to travel either by bus, school bus, taxi or lorry, and he cannot thus be termed as "cargo" because he has the option. It is admitted that, because of the incapacity of the SBS to provide an adequate number of buses for peak hour travel, supplementary schemes have to be put forward, and we should leave it to the commuters to decide how they wish to travel for the money they are prepared to pay. Service is not for free, whether they travel by taxi, public bus, school bus or lorry.

PROBATION AND AFTERCARE SERVICE
(Staff turnover)


    4. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Social Affairs what the turnover rate is in respect of staff in the Probation and Aftercare Service; and if consideration is being given to a review of the terms and conditions of service of the staff in this section of his Ministry.

    The Minister for Social Affairs (Encik Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker, Sir, the average turnover rate of the Probation and Aftercare Officers for the period 1969-73 was about 30 per cent. The figures are as follows: 

   1969  40    per cent

   1970  46    per cent

   1971  20    per cent

   1972  14    per cent

   1973  30    per cent

It gives an average of 30 per cent.

    The problem of recruitment and retention of trained social workers is not peculiar to the Probation and Aftercare Service alone. There is a general shortage of trained social workers in Singapore. Many of them prefer administrative, research and training jobs in the private sector, to field work in the Probation and Aftercare Service. The work of a Probation and Aftercare Officer is specialised and onerous. The Probation

Column: 175

and Aftercare Officer has to work both during and outside of office hours to rehabilitate the offenders through supervision, which involves visits to homes and to places of work of the probationers. This type of work calls for the right attitude and training to help offenders to become socially useful and law-abiding citizens. It requires an officer with high leadership qualities and a strong character. He must be firm and at the same time sympathetic to the problems and needs of offenders and their families. The very specialised nature of the job, the lack of trained social workers, and the more attractive jobs in the private sector are the reasons for the high turnover of staff in the Service.

    My Ministry recognises that with the rising crime and delinquency rate, the Probation and Aftercare Service has a vital part to play in the prevention of juvenile delinquency and the treatment of offenders. To fulfil its role in this aspect of community welfare and redevelopment, the Service has to be made sufficiently attractive, in comparison with other jobs in the civil service and in the private sector, to ensure the recruitment and retention of suitably qualified officers in the existing establishment. Proposals to strengthen the organisational structure of the department by the creation of more promotional posts to enable serving officers to better their prospects, as well as better salaries and conditions of service for officers, have already been submitted to the Ministry of Finance for consideration.

PENSIONERS
(Ex gratia allowance)


    5. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Finance if the Government will give consideration to raising the cost of living allowance of pensioners, to allow them to meet present inflationary conditions; and if the Government will also consider referring the case of pensioners to, say, the National Wages Council for periodic adjustments of their pensions.

Column: 176



    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am happy to announce that Government has decided to grant with effect from 1st April, 1974, an ex gratia allowance to assist pensioners in difficulties in the present abnormal inflationary situation. The ex, gratia payment, to be termed the new Singapore Allowance, will he confined to pensioners resident in Singapore, whose total pension is less than S650 per month and who will have retired before 1st April, 1974.

    Pensioners whose total pension is $100 per month or less will receive an allowance equal to 50 per cent of their pension, subject to a minimum of $15 per month or a maximum of $30 per month. Those whose pensions are above $100 per month but below $650 per month will receive a flat rate of $30 per month, subject to a maximum gross pension of $650 per month. Pensioners with mixed service now resident in Singapore will be paid half the rate. To ascertain total pension, basic pension plus existing Singapore Allowance and Cost of Living Allowance will be aggregated and rounded upwards to the nearest dollar.

    The new Singapore Allowance will also be payable to widows who receive a dependants' pension from the Singapore Government provided they are in receipt of the pension as a result of service put in by their deceased husbands. Persons in receipt of an Injury Allowance which itself is subject to review will not be paid the new Singapore Allowance. Persons who have been retired on disciplinary grounds with reduced pension, other than on grounds of indebtedness will also not be eligible. In order to alleviate the hardship of those retired on account of indebtedness, it has been decided to include them for payment of the allowance.

    On this basis, about 4,000 pensioners will receive the new Singapore Allowance. This will cost the Singapore Government $1.1 million per annum and represents an 11 per cent increase in the pensions bill.

Column: 177



    I would like to stress that this ex gratia allowance to pensioners resident in Singapore is not in any way to be linked with the NWC award for workers. Whereas the NWC award is really a form of supplementary wages to workers which takes into account the performance of the economy and our competitive position in labour costs and productivity, this special ex gratia allowance to pensioners is based on entirely different considerations. Regard was had to the unprecedented rise in the cost of living, particularly in the financial year that is about to end. However, there will not be periodic adjustments. It would be totally inappropriate to refer the matter of payment of pensions to the NWC for consideration. Pensions are paid as a result of pensioners having qualified under their agreed terms of service with the Government.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [4th March, 1974], "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 1974 to 31st March, 1975.". - [Minister for Finance].

    Question again proposed.

3.08 p.m.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (River Valley): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Government's financial policy for the financial year 1974-75 as outlined in the Annual Budget Statement. However, I would like to comment on the policy and its implementation in three particular areas. They are: -

    (1) Government's role in consumer protection;

    (2) Faster development of supporting industries; and

    (3) Development of teachers in the institutions of higher learning and technical officers of public institutions.

    While it is true that there is very little Singapore can do about rising prices caused mainly by external factors, the Government can take steps to ensure that this state of affairs is not further aggravated by unscrupulous manipulators and profiteers.

    I note that the Government has already taken some positive measures to combat rising prices. The setting up of consumer co-operatives, the lifting of tariffs on some imported products, the campaign to educate the public to refrain from hoarding and the public warning given yesterday to traders and manufacturers against profiteering and hoarding, are some of the measures taken by the Government to protect the consumers. While these measures hope to check spiralling prices, they are by themselves not sufficient. I submit that the Government can and must do more to protect the consumers from profiteers and hazards.

Column: 179



    I am aware that the Government has enacted the Sale of Food Act which, among other things, prohibits the sale or use of articles dangerous to health and prevent deception and fraud arising out of the sale of food. The Act also requires labelling to be informative and ethical and covers not only food products, but also appliances intended for use in food preparation. This Act should be more vigorously enforced, including imported products. In addition, there is, however, a need now for the Government to extend protection to include more than food products and appliances for the following reasons.

    The Singapore consumer lives in a consumer paradise and can purchase products from the four corners of the globe in any of our shops and departmental stores. He also leads a hazardous life each day he uses certain products and is liable to be cheated when he makes a particular purchase. For, apart from the regulations governing food, drugs and medicines, almost any other consumer product can be freely imported and sold to the Singapore public. It is unfortunate that we do not have statistics on the injuries or deaths resulting from the use of "hazardous" consumer products.

    If the Government firmly believes that our consumers need to be protected, then the Government must initiate appropriate action to protect the public from the daily hazards of using questionable consumer products and from being cheated. Our buying public is not sophisticated enough or technically competent to differentiate trade marks, quality and misleading specifications. All that most consumers can understand are the differences in prices. The public must therefore be helped where they cannot fully protect themselves. This can be achieved through enacting a new Act to regulate the importation and sale of a wide variety of consumer products, including household products and toys not covered under existing laws. Such an Act will

Column: 180

also encourage and motivate our industries to produce better quality products.

    On the other hand, while we encourage our industries to improve their technology and upgrade quality and to manufacture products for local and overseas markets, we must at the same time ensure that imported products are equally reliable. Otherwise our industries are handicapped to compete even in our own markets and our efforts to motivate our industries to better qualitative heights will be negated.

    We all know of examples of products where the quality is suspect. Many of these are imported products.
